titlePage.docImprint: ENTERED AT STATIONERS ’ HALL ,LONDON. HOLBROOK 'S DRAMATIC READER .

div.p: TO THE CHILDREN These little plays — well-known stories done into dialogue — were written for children who like to imagine themselves living with their favorite characters in forest , in palace , or in fairyland . It is hoped that you will enjoy these old friends in their new dress almost as well as you loved them in the old . When you read the words of bird or tree or prince or child , try to speak with the voice and manner which you think that character would use . Thus you will make the reading a joy to yourselves and a great satisfaction to your hearers . To try to put oneself in the place of another is very good training for the imagination . It also teaches us to be more kind to others and to all living creatures . We learn that most persons are striving to do better and to be better , and we grow in understanding and sympathy . May these little plays help you to the enjoyment of the great dramas which you will read when you are older .

div.head: SCENE II .— Midnight in the Forest

sp.speaker: Jack Frost
sp.p: Here I am in the great forest . How I dislike to touch all these beautiful leaves ; yet I must obey the orders of King Winter . Here comes the Forest Fairy . Do you know why I have come , dear Fairy of the Forest ?

sp.speaker: Forest Fairy
sp.p: Yes , Mr . Frost . I know that you must touch all the leaves , turning them into brilliant hues of gold and crimson and brown . I dislike to have them go , and yet you and I must obey the commands of King Winter . But ,—

sp.speaker: Jack Frost
sp.p: But what , dear Fairy ? You speak as if you had some wish to make — what is it ?

sp.speaker: Forest Fairy
sp.p: I must tell you . Such a dear little bird came to the forest this evening . He had a broken wing , and he was cold and very tired . He asked shelter from the great Oak , the proud Maple , and the graceful Willow ,— and all refused . I was so ashamed of my trees !

sp.speaker: Jack Frost
sp.p: What ! did all the trees refuse to help a poor , tired little bird ?

sp.speaker: Forest Fairy
sp.p: Listen ! just as I was intending to speak to the trees , I heard the Spruce tell him to come to her branches and she would give him shelter . Then the Pine tree offered to keep the north wind from him , and the Juniper gave him her berries to eat . Could you , dear Jack Frost —

sp.speaker: Jack Frost
sp.p: Yes , yes , I know what you would ask . Such kindness as this should meet with some reward . The leaves of the proud Oak , the Maple , and the Willow shall fall to the ground when the cold of winter comes ; but the Spruce , the Pine , the Juniper , and all their family shall keep their leaves and they shall be green all through the year . They shall be called the Evergreen Trees .

I would not take up much room , and I do n't like to be left here by myself when they are having such a good time . Oh , dear ! I believe I 'm going to cry , but I can n't help it .Cries .

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Why are you crying , Cinderella ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Who is that ? I thought I heard some one speaking to me , but I can n't see anybody .

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: What is the matter , Cinderella ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh , lovely lady ! who are you ?

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: I am your fairy godmother , my child , and I wish to know why you are crying .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh , dear ! I 'm crying because they have all gone to the ball ; and I wanted to go , too , and they would n't take me !

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Never mind , my dear . Stop crying , and I will let you go .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh , dear fairy godmamma ! will you , really ? But how can I go in this old dress ?

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: You 'll see . Tell me , Cinderella , have you a big yellow pumpkin in the kitchen garden ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Yes , I think so . I saw one there yesterday .

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Go , get it for me . Cinderellaruns out , and returns with the pumpkinI 've found it ! Here it is !

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Yes , that is a fine pumpkin . I 'll touch it with my wand . What is it now ?

div.stage: The pumpkin is changed to a carriage .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh ! oh ! how lovely ! Such a beautiful , big , yellow coach ! Why , it is much finer than papa 's black carriage .

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: I am glad you like your coach . Now do you think there are any rats in your rat trap ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: I 'll go see . Yes , here is the trap with two big rats in it . What long tails they have !

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Wait till I touch them with my fairy wand . Now what do you see ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh , dear godmother ! what a wonderful wand to change rats into great handsome horses with long manes and tails ! You dear horses ! I 'll get you some sugar to eat .

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Do n't stop to pet them now , but fetch me the mousetrap .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Here it is with two cunning little mice in it . What will you do with them ?

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Touch them with my fairy wand and turn them into a coachman and a footman . See , the coachman is on the box with the reins in his hand , and the footman holds the door open for you . Will you step in , Cinderella ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: In these clothes , dear godmother ? Fairy GodmotherlaughingThat would n't be nice , would it ? Well , let us see what my wand can do for you . Now look in the glass and tell me what you see there .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Oh , what a pretty lady ! Why , I do believe she is myself ! What a beautiful dress ! And look , dear godmother ! see my pretty glass slippers !

sp.speaker: Fairy Godmother
sp.p: Yes , my dear , you are all ready for the Prince 's ball . I want you to have a happy time , but remember this . You must start for home when the clock strikes twelve or your pretty clothes will change , your coach will turn into a pumpkin , your horses to rats , and you will have to walk home .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: I 'll remember , dear godmother , and run away on the first stroke . Thank you so much ! Good-by !

div.stage: Enters the coach and is driven away .

div.head: SCENE III .— The Prince 's Palace

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Here I am at the palace . Please announce me as the Lady from Far Away .

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: The Lady from Far Away !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What a lovely lady ! she must be a princess . Tell me , fair lady , are you a princess from the land of flowers ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: I am not a princess , sir , but only a girl from the land of happy thoughts .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You say well , fair lady , for no one can look upon you without thoughts of love and joy .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: And you , great Prince , have thoughts of great and noble deeds , have you not ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Yes , I have thoughts of great deeds , of brave men and fair ladies , of games and victories ,— but now I have forgotten all but you .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Will you remember me to-morrow or shall I fade away like the dreams of night ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: No dreams could be fairer , but I hope you will not vanish as they do . If you do , I am quite sure that I shall find you !

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Do n't be too sure , for I am not what I seem . I am a princess only in your thoughts ; really I am —

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What ? a flower , a star , a goddess ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: No , only a woman —

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: The best of all , a woman ! And now will the dream-woman dance with me ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: With pleasure ; what lovely music !— and so many pretty women . What beautiful rooms !

div.stage: Cinderella , the Prince , her father , mother , sisters , and two gentlemen dance the minuet .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Will you not tell me your name and where you live ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Both are a secret .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: It makes no difference to me , for I know you , and that is enough .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: I hear the clock ! What hour is it striking ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Twelve — but that is early . You need not go ?

lg.l: Yes , I must , and quietly . Do not try to keep me ,
Prince — good night !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: She is gone ! and I do not know where she lives . How can I find her ? I 'll give another ball and hope she will come again .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Well , girlies , did you have a pleasant time at the ball ?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: Oh , yes , papa , splendid ! But did you see the lovely princess that came so late ?

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: She was the prettiest girl there . I wonder who she is !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: So do I . It seems to me I 've seen her somewhere . Perhaps I 've met her in my travels ; but I can n't remember where it was .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: What is her name ?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: I heard some one say she was Lady Far Away . But that 's not a real name .

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: Perhaps she is a princess in disguise .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Tell me , sister , how this princess looked .

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: Oh ! she is lovely ! Golden curls and blue eyes and such a sweet smile !

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: She wore a beautiful dress that shone like the moonlight .

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: Did you notice her pretty slippers ? They looked like crystal .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: The Prince danced with her all the time .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Why , here comes the Prince 's herald . I 'll see what he wants . Here is a note . It is an invitation to go to the Prince 's palace again to-night . Do you all want to go ?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Yes , yes , father , please !

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: All right , we 'll go !

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Ca n't I go this time , mamma ?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: No , my dear . When you are a little older you can go , but not now .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: I wonder if my fairy princess will come to-night . I 've been looking for her for more than an hour . Oh , here she is ! Dear lady , I 've been hoping you would come .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: So you have not forgotten me ?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: No , and never shall . Will you go with me to see the flowers ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: What lovely flowers ! This is certainly the home of the flower fairies . See the roses nodding at us . They almost ask us to love them .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: May I give you this dainty pink one ? It is the color of your cheeks .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Remember I am from the land of Far Away and I must vanish at midnight .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Tell me where your father lives that I may call upon him .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Not now ; but sometime I may tell you about my fairy godmother .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: There ! I knew you must be a sister of the fairies . Does your fairy godmother have a fairy wand ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Yes , and she does wonderful things with it — but my father and mother do not know about her .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Of course not . Only very young people know about fairy godmothers . But we know , do n't we ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Hark ! I hear the chimes ringing . It must be twelve o'clock , and I must go .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Do not go , dear princess . Stay here in my palace , always .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: The fairies are calling me and I am late . I must go . Perhaps I can come again sometime . Oh , I am afraid —

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Afraid of what ?

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Good-by , good-by !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: She 's gone ! What was she afraid of ? I cannot see her ! Who is that child running down the stairway ? She must be one of the servants who has been watching the dancers . I wish I could see my princess . What is that shining thing on the stairs ? She has lost one of her crystal slippers . Now I know how I shall find her . To-morrow I shall send a herald through the city to find the owner of this pretty little slipper .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Mamma , mamma , here is a man on horseback who wants to see you .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What is your errand , sir ?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: I am sent by the great Prince of our country to find the owner of this slipper . He says he will marry no one but the lady who can wear this little crystal slipper .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: I 'll call my daughters . Katherine ! Elizabeth ! We were all at the ball at the Prince 's palace . Katherine , is this your glass slipper ? Try it on .

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: Yes , mother . My , how small it is ! I cannot get my foot in it !

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: Perhaps it will fit me . My feet are smaller than yours . No , I cannot push my foot in , no matter how long I try . It must be a magic slipper .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: May I try on the slipper ?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: My dear child , why should you try on the slipper ? It belongs to the princess who went to the ball .

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: And you were not at the ball , Cinderella !

sp.speaker: Elizabeth
sp.p: Your foot is too big for it , my dear little sister .

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Pardon me , ladies , but the orders of the Prince are that every lady , young or old , must try on the slipper , and when the owner is found she must go with me to the palace .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Give it to me , please . See how easily it slips on my foot — and here is the mate to the glass slipper in my pocket . Dear Mother , I am the fairy princess you saw at the ball .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: You , my dear ! and I did not know you !

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Now , lady , please come with me to the Prince 's palace . You shall be a princess .

sp.speaker: Cinderella
sp.p: Good-by , dear sisters ! Good-by , dear mother ! I am going to the Prince 's palace .

castItem.roleDesc: TEN CITIZENS , PIPER SCENE I .— The Mayor 's Office

castItem.role: Mayor and Councilmen
castItem.roleDesc: sitting around a table .— Citizens come in

castItem.role: First Citizen . Our Mayor is a noddy !
Second Citizen . Look at our corporation sitting in the gowns we pay for
castItem.roleDesc: and doing nothing !

castItem.role: Third Citizen . See here
castItem.roleDesc: how the rats made a nest in my Sunday hat !

figure.p: Illustration ] Fourth Citizen . When I was cooking dinner the bold rats licked the soup from my ladle ! Fifth Citizen . They are so bold they are always fighting with the dogs and cats ! Sixth Citizen . Yes , and they kill them , too ! Seventh Citizen . My baby cried in his sleep , and when I went to him there was a big rat in his cradle . Eighth Citizen . What are you going to do about it , Mr. Mayor ? Ninth Citizen . You 'd better wake up , sirs ! Do n't go to sleep over this ! Tenth Citizen . I tell you , you 'll have to do something to save us from this army of rats ! First Councilman . What can we do ? Second Councilman . I 'm sure we 've tried everything , but every day the rats grow worse and worse . Third Councilman . I 'm sure it is n't very pleasant for us to have the city overrun with the creatures ! Mayor . I 'd sell my ermine gown for a guilder ! It is no easy thing to be mayor and I wish I was a plowboy in the country ! Try to think of something to do . First Councilman . It is easy to bid us rack our own brains ! Second Councilman . I 'm sure my head aches trying to think . Third Councilman . I 've wondered and thought , till I 've no thoughts left . Mayor . Oh ! if I only had a great big trap ! Yes , a thousand big traps ! Bless us , what noise is that ? Is it a rat ?— Come in ! [ Illustration ] [ Enter Piper . ] First Councilman . Who is this who dares to come into the Mayor 's office without an introduction ? Second Councilman . Has n't he a funny coat ? Third Councilman . But what a pleasant face ! He smiles all the time . Mayor . He looks like the picture of my grandsire . What is your name , and your business , my man ? Pied Piper . Please your honors , my name is Pied Piper . My business is to play upon my pipe . I can charm with the magic of my notes all things to do my will . But I use my charm on creatures that do people harm , the toad , the mole , and the viper , and rats — rats ! Mayor . Rats ! Well , then , you 're the man we want . We 'll pay you a thousand guilders if you 'll free our town of rats . Piper . A thousand guilders ! Done ! It 's a bargain !

div.head: SCENE II .— Same as Scene I . The Mayor and Councilmen looking out of

stage.stage: window

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: There he goes down the street .

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: What a strange looking pipe he plays !

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: I believe it must be a magic one .

sp.speaker: Third Councilman
sp.p: Do you hear the music ? What is that other noise ?

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Look , look at the rats ! Did you ever see such a sight !

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: The streets are crowded with them ! Big and little , brown , black , and gray , they are tumbling over each other in their hurry !

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: Sir ! he is going toward the bridge .

sp.speaker: Third Councilman
sp.p: They must think he is playing a tune of apples and cheese !

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: There they are at the river . They are plunging in ! they will be drowned !

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: Good for the piper !

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Ring the bells for the people . Tell them to get long poles , poke out the nests and block up the holes !

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: Here comes the Piper .

sp.speaker: Third Councilman
sp.p: That was well done , Mr. Piper .

sp.speaker: Pied Piper
sp.p: Yes , all the rats are drowned and now I 've come for my pay .

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Pay ! why what have you done ? Just played a tune on your pipe . You must be joking .

sp.speaker: Piper
sp.p: You promised —

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: You impudent fellow ! You certainly do n't think a tune on your pipe is worth one thousand guilders ? There is no work in that .

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: The rats are dead and can n't come to life again , I think !

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: My friend , we are much obliged , of course . We are much obliged and will gladly give you fifty guilders . You know your time is not worth more .

sp.speaker: Piper
sp.p: No trifling , pray . I 'll have what you promised , or you may find that I 'll play a tune you do not like !

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: What ! do you threaten us , fellow ? Do what you please . Do you think we care ? Play on your old pipe whatever tune you wish .

sp.speaker: Piper
sp.p: Listen , then , and look from your window when I play again in the street below .

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: What does the lazy fellow mean by his threats ?

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: Hear his wonderful music ! Listen .

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: Oh ! what is he doing ! See the children !

sp.speaker: Third Councilman
sp.p: They are following him . There is my son . Where are you going , my boy ? Come back !

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Let me see ! O woe ! there are my own three lovely children . Run , some one , and stop them !

sp.speaker: Third Councilman
sp.p: I 'll go ; I 'll go .

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: It is useless . Every child in our city is following the magic sound .

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: The music seems to say : “ Come , children , to the wonderful land of play . There flowers and fruits will welcome you . The birds and beasts will play with you , and you will never be sad or sorry in the wonderful land of play . ” No wonder the children follow the Piper . Third CouncilmanentersThe children and the Piper have all disappeared ! A mountain opened and let them in !

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: The children , the blessed children , have gone ! What shall we do without the children ?

lg.l: Oh , wicked man that I am ! Why did I break my promise ? Why did
I not give him the thousand guilders ?

sp.speaker: Second Councilman
sp.p: Yes , we are all wicked men , and we are punished for not keeping our word .

sp.speaker: Mayor
sp.p: Let us write this sad story on a column so that all may read ; and let us paint the picture of the Piper with our little ones following him , on a church window , so that all men may know how our children have been stolen away .

sp.speaker: First Councilman
sp.p: And may this sad story teach us all to keep our word with every one .

div.head: SCENE I .— Home of Mother Goose

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: I really think I must give a party . All my friends have been so good to me and I have been entertained in so many homes ! Wherever I go I am sure to see one of my Mother Goose books , and the children all seem to love it so much . Let me see ! whom shall I invite ? I think I 'll ask Old Mother Hubbard to take tea with me and we 'll talk about the party together . Jack , Jack ! JackentersYes , mother dear , what is it ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Jack Goose , I wish you to run over to Mother Hubbard 's house and ask her to take tea with me this afternoon . Now be nimble , Jack ,— be quick !

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Yes , mother dear . See me jump over the candlestick ! Is n't that fine jumping ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Very fine indeed , Jack . Now do your errand , and hurry home .

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Yes , mother , I will . Good-by .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Good-by .

div.head: SCENE II .— House of Mother Hubbard

stage.stage: Jack ( knocking ) . I wonder if Old Mother Hubbard is at home . Hark ! I hear her dog barking . Yes , and I hear her step . Here she is !
Mother Hubbard ( opening the door ) . Who is this knocking so loud ? Oh , it 's you , little nimble Jack ! Will you come in ?

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: No , thank you , Mrs. Hubbard . My mother wishes you to come over to our house for tea this afternoon . Will you come ?

lg.l: Yes , thank you , Jack , I will . Tell your mother that
I 'm just going to market to buy my poor doggie a bone .

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: O Mother Hubbard ! please let me play with your dog . He 's such a dear old doggie ! Do you remember how he danced a jig the other day ?

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: Yes , Jack , I do ; and I think you danced with him . You are both nimble young things and both like to dance . Well , good-by , now . Have a good time together and I 'll bring you something little boys like .

lg.l: Thank you ! Good-by , good-by ! Now , doggie , let 's dance .
Old Mother Hubbard , she went to the cupboard ,
To get the poor doggie a bone ;
But when she got there , the cupboard was bare ,
And so the poor doggie had none .
Dog
Bow-wow , bow-wow , bow-wow !
Oh ! you do n't like that song ! Never mind , old fellow ! Mother
Hubbard has gone to the butcher 's and she 'll get you a bone , I 'm sure .
Wait till she comes back .
Dog
Bow-wow , bow-wow , bow-wow !

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: I thought you would like that . Here she comes now . We 've had a lovely dance , Mother Hubbard , and now I must hurry home .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: Thank you for staying and taking good care of my dog . Here are some fresh Banbury buns for you .

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Oh , thank you , Mother Hubbard . I 'm very fond of Banbury buns . Good-by !

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: Good-by , Jack . Tell your mother I 'll be over soon .

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Bring your dog with you , and we 'll have another dance . Good-by .

sp.speaker: Dog
sp.p: Bow-wow ! bow-wow ! bow-wow !

div.head: SCENE III .— Mother Goose and Mother Hubbard at the Tea Table

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: I am pleased to see you , Mother Hubbard . I hear that your cupboard is no longer bare and empty , and I am very glad you are able to give your poor dog all the bones a good dog should have . Now for our tea . Shall I put two or three lumps in your cup ?

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: Three , please . I like my tea very sweet . And now tell me , Mother Goose , what is the reason you sent for me to-day ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Well , I am going to give a party and I wish to ask your advice .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: Indeed ! Whom do you think of inviting ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: First , the dear Old Woman who lives in the shoe —

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: What ! and all her children ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: No , only the two eldest . You know the party is for my son Jack , too , and we must have the young people as well as their parents . Old King Cole will come and bring his fiddlers three to play for the young folks who dance .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: I hope you wo n't invite Tom the Piper 's Son , or My Son John as his mother calls him ,— or Humpty-Dumpty . They are not good boys for your son Jack to play with !

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: I suppose not ; but I like them all , and I dislike to leave out anyone . I do n't wish to hurt their feelings .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: There are little Bo-Peep and Boy Blue , who are good children , although rather silly ; and there are little Miss Muffet and Nancy Etticoat , both very pretty little girls ; and there are Jacky Horner and Tommy Tucker and the Man-in-the-Moon and Taffey and Daffey-Down-Dilly and —

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: I 'll have to give a garden party if I invite all those ! I can n't leave any out , and I think I 'll have the party out-of-doors .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: That will be fine ! I only hope it will be a pleasant day . When will you give it ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Two weeks from to-day , the first of May .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: That 's May Day and a very good day for a party out-of-doors . Well I must go home now . Good-by ! If I can help you , please call upon me .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Thank you , Mother Hubbard ! Good-by , and thank you again for coming over .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: What a lovely day you have for your party , Mother Goose ! The sun shines so bright and warm , and the flowers are lovely . Is there anything I can do ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: No , thank you . I 'm glad you came early . Have you seen the tables ?

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: They are lovely ! Where did you get such pretty flowers ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: From Mistress Mary , quite contrary . You know she has a garden With cockle shells , and silver bells , And pretty maids all in a row .

sp.speaker: Mother Hubbard
sp.p: I see some one coming .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Why , how do you do , A-Dillar-a-Dollar ! Are you always in such good time ? A-Dillar-a-Dollar . I 'm afraid not , Mrs . Goose . They call me A ten o'clock scholar , Why did you come so soon ? You used to come at ten o'clock , And now you come at noon !

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: And here comes Mary with her little lamb . Do you like the lamb better than a Teddy Bear , Mary ?

lg.l: Yes , indeed , I do . Because the lamb loves me , you know .
It followed me to school one day ,
Which was against the rule ;
It made the children laugh and play ,
To see the lamb at school .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Here comes the Old Woman who lives in a shoe , and her two oldest boys . Dear Mrs. Shoe-woman , I am very glad to see you ! How did you leave all of your children ?

sp.speaker: Mrs
sp.p: Shoe-woman . Oh , dear , Mother Goose ! I have so many children I do n't know what to do : when they are naughty I give them some broth without any bread , and whip them all soundly and put them to bed .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Here are all the children coming to the party ! Come , children , let us have a dance . All stand around the Maypole as I call your names : Little Miss Muffet and Boy Blue ; Little Bo-Peep and Jacky Horner ; Nancy Etticoat and Jack-be-nimble ; Mary and the little Boy who lives in the Lane . All take ribbons and stand around the Maypole . Are you all ready ?

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Yes , Mother Goose , we are all ready when the music begins .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Old King Cole , will you have your three fiddlers play for the dance ?

lg.l: With pleasure , dear Mother Goose — and I 'll sing :
Hey diddle , diddle ! the cat and the fiddle ;
The cow jumped over the moon ;
The little dog laughed to see such craft ,
And the dish ran away with the spoon .
Children
Old King Cole was a merry old soul ;
And a merry old soul was he ;
He called for his pipe and he called for his bowl ,
And he called for his fiddlers three .
These are very good songs , but they will not do for a
Maypole dance . Here , Little Tommy Tucker , sing for your supper .
All right , Mother Goose .
Handy Spandy , Jack-a-dandy ,
Loved plum cake and sugar candy ;
He bought some at a grocer 's shop ,
And out he came , hop , hop , hop .
Children .
Little Tommy Tucker , sings for his supper ;
What shall he eat ? White bread and butter ;
How shall he eat it without any knife ?
How shall he marry without any wife ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Why , who can that man be ? He is tumbling down in a very queer way ! Who are you ? Man . I 'm the Man in the Moon , Come down too soon To ask the way to Norwich . I went by the south , And burnt my mouth , Eating cold pease-porridge . Are Jack and Jill here ?

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Here I am , Mr. Moon-Man .

sp.speaker: Jill
sp.p: Oh , dear Mr. Moon-Man , where is your dog and your bundle of sticks ?

sp.speaker: Jack
sp.p: Tell us what the children play in your country , the Moon !

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Please do , Mr. Moon-Man ! Moon-Man . Well , children , I can tell you how they learn to count . They all say — One , two ; buckle my shoe ; Three , four ; shut the door ; Five , six ; pick up sticks ; and then they all pick up sticks and put them on the fire .

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I do n't think that is much fun !

lg.l: Of course you do n't . You do n't like sticks .
Tom , Tom , the Piper 's Son ,
Stole a pig and away he run !
The pig was eat ,
And Tom was beat ,
And Tom ran roaring down the street !

sp.speaker: Mistress Mary
sp.p: Now , children , let us sit in a circle and play games and sing songs . Little Bo-Peep , you may sing your little song first . Little Bo-Peep . Little Bo-Peep , she lost her sheep , And does n't know where to find them ; Children . Leave them alone and they will come home Bringing their tails behind them .

lg.l: Now Jack and Jill —
Jack and Jill . Shall we go up the hill to get a pail of water ?
Children .
Jack and Jill went up the hill
To get a pail of water .
Jack fell down and broke his crown ,
And Jill came tumbling after .
Boys .
Up Jack got and home did trot
As fast as he could caper ;
He went to bed to mend his head ,
With vinegar and brown paper .
Girls .
Jill came in and she did grin ,
To see his paper plaster ;
Her mother , vexed , did spank her next
For laughing at Jack 's disaster .

sp.speaker: Mistress Mary
sp.p: Now , I 'll sing a song and then help Mother Goose with the supper .Sings .Sing a song a sixpence , Pocket full of rye ; Four-and-twenty blackbirds Baked in a pie . When the pie was opened The birds began to sing , Was n't that a dainty dish To set before the king ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Now I must have some children to help me .

sp.speaker: Jack Goose
sp.p: I 'll take the bean porridge hot and bean porridge cold , mother , and Tommy Tucker can go with me and pass the white bread and butter .

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: That 's my good Jack . Now Tom the Piper 's Son may take the roast pig and Mary may pass the Banbury cross buns .

sp.speaker: Miss Muffet
sp.p: Dear Mother Goose , may I pass the curds and whey ?

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Yes , my dear child , but be careful not to spill any . Then for the last course Jack Horner will pass the Christmas pie and give every child a big fat plum . ChildrensingLittle Jacky Horner Sitting in a corner Eating a Christmas pie He put in his thumb And pulled out a plum And said — What a great boy am I ? Old King Cole . Mother Goose , you have given us a beautiful party and we have had a lovely time . We hope you will live to give many more to your friends and the children .

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Yes , Mother Goose , your party was just lovely !

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Thank you , dear children .

lg.l: Now , little folks , let us sing a good-by song to Mother
Goose .
The girls
The king was in the counting room ,
Counting out his money .
The boys
The queen was in the parlor ,
Eating bread and honey .
All .
The maid was in the garden
Hanging out the clothes ,
Along came a blackbird
And nipped off her nose !

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: And that story means that night is coming and putting the day to sleep .

sp.speaker: King Cole
sp.p: So it does , and you see the sun is fast going down behind the western hills . Say good-by , children , for it is time to go home .

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Good night , Mother Goose .

lg.l: Good night , dear children , and do n't forget your old
Mother Goose .

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Forget dear Mother Goose ? Never ! Good-by , good-by !

sp.speaker: Mother Goose
sp.p: Good-by .

castItem.role: THREE-EYES , LITTLE OLD WOMAN , TREE , PRINCE , GOAT

div.head: SCENE I .— Dining Room at Little Two-Eyes ’ Home

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Come to dinner , little One-Eye and little Three-Eyes . Here is some good soup and white bread for you . Little Two-Eyes , you can have what your sisters do not want . Little Three-Eyes . Here 's a crust for you . That is enough for a girl with only two eyes . Little One-Eye . What a shame to have a sister with two eyes ! You look just like other people ! Little Three-Eyes and I are very different . Little Three-Eyes . Here little Two-Eyes , take this bowl . I do n't want any more and you can have what is left .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Now , children , run away and play . Little Two-Eyes , take the goat and go out to the hillside . You must stay till it begins to get dark , and then you may come home . You must work , because you have two eyes like other people , but my little One-Eye and Three-Eyes may stay at home and play .

stage.stage: Little Two-Eyes . Come , little goat , here is some green grass for you to eat . I wish that my sisters loved me and that my mother was not ashamed of me . Oh , why do I have two eyes just like all other people ? I am so hungry , Oh , dear ! Oh , dear ! ( Cries . )

sp.speaker: Wood Fairy
sp.p: My child , why do you cry ? Little Two-Eyes . Because I have only two eyes , and my mother and my sisters treat me badly . I do n't have enough to eat and I am so hungry . My dress is old , and my sisters have nice dresses and pretty ribbons . But who are you ?

sp.speaker: Wood Fairy
sp.p: I am the little Old Woman who lives on this hill . I have come to help you . Listen , little Two-Eyes ! You need never be hungry again . Say to your little goat : Little goat , bleat ! Little table , rise ! Then a table will rise before you with all the food you can eat . When you have finished eating , you must say : Little goat , bleat ! Little table , away ! and it will disappear before your eyes . Good-by , dear little Two-Eyes . I must go now , but remember what I have told you . Little Two-Eyes . Why , where has that queer looking little woman gone ? I am so hungry I 'll try now if what she said can be true . Little goat , bleat ! Little table , rise !

sp.speaker: Goat
sp.p: Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Little Two-Eyes . Oh , look , little goat ! what a pretty table ! and how good the food looks . Now we shall have all we want to eat . Here is something for you , and here are oranges and meat and pudding for me ! Dear little woman ! How can I thank her ? Now I can eat no more . Little goat , bleat ! Little table , away !

sp.speaker: Goat
sp.p: Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Little Two-Eyes . There , it is gone . Are n't we happy , little goat ? But see , it is time to go home . Come , little goat .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Here , little Two-Eyes , here are the crusts your sisters saved for you . Two-Eyes . Thank you , mother , but I do n't care for any crusts . I 'm not hungry .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Not care for them ? You are not hungry ? You have always eaten them before now and asked for more ! You did n't eat any supper last night , either . What does this mean ? What did you have to eat to-day ? Two-Eyes . I cannot tell you , mother .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: You cannot ? Then , little One-Eye , you shall go to the hillside with little Two-Eyes and find out why she is no longer hungry . Little One-Eye . I do n't want to go ! The walk is too long , and I shall get tired !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Just this once , my dear ! You will not have to go again . But we must learn the secret . Little Two-Eyes . Come , sister . Come , little goat .

stage.stage: Little Two-Eyes . Now we are almost there . Are you tired , little One-Eye ?
Little One-Eye . Oh ! I am so tired , and my feet hurt so I can hardly walk .
Little Two-Eyes . I have to walk this far every day .
Little One-Eye . Yes , but you have two eyes like other people and you must expect to work . I cannot go any farther . I 'll lie down here and rest .
Little Two-Eyes . I 'll sing you a pretty song :
Are you awake , little One-Eye ? Are you asleep , little One-Eye ?
Yes , you are asleep , little One-Eye , and now I can have my dinner .
Little goat , bleat ! Little table , rise !

sp.speaker: Goat
sp.p: Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Little Two-Eyes . Here is the little table again ! Oh , how thankful I am for the good food . Dear little old woman , you are very good to send me such nice things to eat . Here is some for you , little goat . Now I have had enough . Little goat , bleat ! Little table , away ! There , it is gone . Little One-Eye , wake up ! It is time to go home . Little One-Eye . Did I go to sleep ? Little Two-Eyes . Indeed , you did , and now we must hurry home . Come , little goat !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Well , little One-Eye , tell us what you have seen . Why does n't little Two-Eyes eat the food we have for her ? Little One-Eye . I do n't know , mother . The way was so long and I was so tired ; I fell asleep ; and when I woke up it was time to come home .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: It was a hard walk for you , my dear ; but we must find out who is giving little Two-Eyes something to eat . To-morrow you must go , little Three-Eyes . Little Three-Eyes . I 'll find out , mother . If anyone dares to give food to little Two-Eyes , I 'll tell you all about it .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Yes , my dear , I know you wo n't go to sleep . I can trust you to find out everything .

stage.stage: Little Two-Eyes . Come , sister , we must go on , for it is a long way to the top of the hill .
Little Three-Eyes . I 'm not going any farther , I 'm too tired ! I 'll rest a little here .
Little Two-Eyes . All right , little Three-Eyes . I 'll sing you a song .
Are you awake , little Three-Eyes ? Are you asleep , little Two-Eyes ?
Yes , you are asleep , and now I 'll have my dinner .
Little goat , bleat ! Little table , rise !

sp.speaker: Goat
sp.p: Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Bla-a ! Little Two-Eyes . Here is our dinner again , little goat . See this fresh lettuce and cabbage and good bread and butter . Here is some honey , too , and cake . Is n't this a good dinner ? Little goat , bleat ! Little table , away !

lg.l: Bla-a , bla-a , bla-a !
Little Two-Eyes . Now it is gone . Three-Eyes , wake up ! It is time home .
Little Three-Eyes . How long I have slept ! What will my mother say ? But
I think I have a surprise for you , little Two-Eyes !

sp.speaker: SCENE VII
sp.p: — At Home

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Well , little Three-Eyes , did you go to sleep , too ? Little Three-Eyes .— Yes , mother , but only with two eyes . Little Two-Eyes sang to me , “ Are you awake , little Three-Eyes ? Are you asleep , little Two-Eyes ? ” and so two of my eyes went to sleep , but one stayed awake and watched .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What did you see ? Tell me quickly , dear little Three-Eyes . Little Three-Eyes . First she said , “ Little goat , bleat ! Little table , rise ! ” and the goat said , “ Bla-a , bla-a , bla-a ! ” Then a table came up out of the ground . Oh ! it was such a pretty little table with a white cloth over it and all kinds of good things on it . No wonder little Two-Eyes does n't eat any of our common food . It is n't good enough for her ! She has food fit for a queen ,— nuts and cake , and candy , too !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: So that is why little Two-Eyes does n't eat the crusts we save for her ! Well , I 'll see if she is going to have better food , than we have . Bring me the long sharp knife .Goes out and soon returns .There , now the goat is dead . Little Two-Eyes , perhaps you 'll eat the food we give you now ! Little Two-Eyes . Oh , my poor little goat ! What shall I do without it !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Go to bed , and to-morrow morning you shall go to the hillside alone . And you must stay there all day , too .

stage.stage: Little Two-Eyes . Oh , dear ! Oh , dear ! my poor goat is dead ! Now I shall be hungry and lonely too ! Where shall I go , and what can I do ?
Little Wood Fairy . Little Two-Eyes , why are you weeping ?
Little Two-Eyes . Because my mother has killed my poor goat , and she has sent me here to stay all alone , and I am so hungry and thirsty again .

Little Wood Fairy . Little Two-Eyes , let me tell you what to do . Ask your sisters to give you the heart of your goat . Bury it in the ground before the house door . Watch , and to-morrow a wonderful tree will come up out of the ground .
Little Two-Eyes . Thank you , dear little woman ! I 'll go home and do as you have told me .

sp.speaker: SCENE IX
sp.p: — At Home Little Two-Eyes . Little One-Eye and little Three-Eyes , please let me have the heart of my goat ! One-Eye . Certainly , if that is all you want . Three-Eyes . Here it is , but I do n't see what you want it for ! Little Two-Eyesgoes to doorNow I 'll plant it as the little woman told me . I wonder what kind of a tree will appear to-morrow ? Poor little goat , I 'm so sorry you have gone ! Now I must go into the house and try to sleep .

sp.speaker: SCENE X
sp.p: — In the Garden Little One-Eye . Mamma , mamma , look here ! Come quickly ! Is n't this a wonderful tree !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Why , how strange ! This tree was not here yesterday . I wonder how it came ! I never saw such a beautiful tree before ! Little One-Eye . Do you see the golden apples on it ? O mamma ! may we have some ? Please , mother !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Yes , dear little One-Eye . You are the oldest , climb up into the tree and pick some golden apples for us . One-Eye . That will be fun . Here I go !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Why do n't you get the apples , little One-Eye ? Little One-Eye . They all get away from me . When I try to pick one it springs back !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Come down , little One-Eye . Now little Three-Eyes , you can see better with your three eyes , than your sister with her one eye . You may climb up and get some apples for us . Little Three-Eyes . I 'll pick a lot of them and throw them down for you to catch . Why , how funny they act ! I almost get one and it always springs away !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Come down and let me try . I never heard of fruit that would not be picked . Now children , I 'll get some of the lovely apples for you . There ! Why , what is the matter ? I can n't reach a single apple . Little Two-Eyes . Let me try ; perhaps I can pick some .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: You , with your two eyes ! How can you expect to get them if we can n't ? Little Two-Eyes . Please let me try , mother .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Well , I suppose you can try , but I know you can n't get them . Two-Eyes . Here they are . Catch them , mother ; catch them , little One-Eye ! Oh , mother ! I see a young man on horseback coming along the road . He looks like a prince .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Hurry down , little Two-Eyes ! He must not see you ,— a girl with two eyes ! I 'm ashamed of you . Hide under this barrel !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Good morning , ladies , what a lovely tree you have here ! She who gives me a branch shall have whatever she wishes . Little One-Eye . The tree is ours , Great Prince ; but when we try to get its fruit , it slips away from us .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: It is strange , if the tree belongs to you , that you cannot get the fruit ! But where do these apples come from ? Little Three-Eyes . We have another sister , but she has only two eyes and we are ashamed of her ; so we hid her under this barrel , and she has rolled the apples out to you .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Little Two-Eyes , come out . Can you get me a branch from this wonderful tree ? Little Two-Eyes . Yes , Prince ; here is a branch with many golden apples on it .

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And what is your wish , little Two-Eyes ? Little Two-Eyes . O Prince ! My mother and my sisters are ashamed of me and do not treat me well . They do not give me enough to eat and they do not like to have me near them . Please take me away where I can be happy and free !

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Come with me , little Two-Eyes ; you shall go to my father 's palace and be a little princess . There you will be happy and free and never be hungry or lonely again .

stage.head: THE DAYS OF THE WEEK
THE WEEK — MONDAY , TUESDAY , WEDNESDAY , THURSDAY , FRIDAY , SATURDAY , SUNDAY

sp.speaker: Monday
sp.p: Well , I am glad to be here at last . Certainly my work is very important . As the first working day of the week , I begin all business ; and I have always heard that if a thing is well begun , it is half done . People call me Moon-day — is n't that a pretty name , the day of the moon ? How beautiful the moon is , riding in her silver chariot across the dark blue sky ! I am proud of my name . The moon is constantly changing and I like change . I like brightness and cleanliness too , and good housewives wash their clothes on Monday . How white and clean they look hanging on the line ! The sun and wind play hide and seek and help to cleanse the clothes . School begins on Monday and the little children run and laugh on their way to school . Every one seems happy that another week has begun .

sp.speaker: Tuesday
sp.p: I am named for Tui , the god of war . In the countries of the north I am greatly honored by all the people . Soldiers when going to war call on Tui for help , and they like to begin a battle on Tuesday . Monday likes to begin work , but I like to make some progress . The children always know their lessons better on Tuesday , and are happier than on Monday . The white clothes are sprinkled and rolled , and now the maids iron the pretty baby dresses and the house linen . They sing and laugh over their work . The world is all running smoothly on Tuesday , and I think I like my work the best .

sp.speaker: Wednesday
sp.p: I should be the best of days , for I am named for Woden , or Odin , the king of the gods . The hardest work of the week is finished when I come , and there is time for a rest . Perhaps mother will bake a special cake for dinner . To-day the children take their music lessons , and the boys go for a lesson in swimming or gymnastic exercise . This is the day young people choose for their wedding day , and you do n't know how glad I am to be a part of their happiness . I believe I have more sunshine than the other days , for Woden likes to have clear skies and health-giving breezes . I would not change with any of my sister days .

sp.speaker: Thursday
sp.p: I bring the thunder and the lightning , and I cleave the dark clouds with my rapid flashes . I glory in a storm , for Thor , the god of thunder , has chosen me for his day , and I bear his name . A life of ease and quiet has no charms for me . I like the din and crash of war , the noise and hurry of business . The fury of the heavens , the crash of falling trees , the roaring of waters ,— what can give greater pleasure ? Business thrives on Thursday . Men rush to and fro , buying and selling , building great houses , digging in the mines , and sailing the seas . Life and action are my delight . Hurrah for Thor 's day !

sp.speaker: Friday
sp.p: After the bustle and work of the week I come to clean and settle all disturbances . Now dirt and dust must disappear under the broom and brush . How the windows shine and how spotless is the hearth ! Children rake up the leaves and burn them ; all rubbish must be cleared away . Order and neatness I love ; and so does Freya , for whom I am named . She is the goddess of beauty , and there is no beauty where neatness and order are absent . Some say that I am an unlucky day , but that is a mistake . See what wonderful things have happened on my day , what great men have been born on Friday ! I am the last school day of the week , and to-day the children may forget lessons and play outdoors a little longer . To-day the family gather for a story at the twilight hour , and all is rest and happiness .

sp.speaker: Saturday
sp.p: I am the jolly day of the week . “ School is out ! ” the children cry , and all day long they sing and call to each other in their games . To-day I smell the cakes and pies cooking in the range , for Saturday is baking day . How the little children love to watch mother stirring the cake and frosting , and how they beg to clean the sweet stuff out of the bowl . Father comes home earlier to-day , and all go for a walk in the woods or park . All men need a holiday , for “ all work and no play makes Jack a dull boy . ” The boys play ball and run and shout in their joy . The girls have little parties , and cook gives them some fresh cakes . I am named for Saetere , god of the harvest , and he is always merry . So I wish all people to be happy on Saturday , the play day of the week .

sp.speaker: Sunday
sp.p: You have all spoken well , my sisters , and each one has some claim to be the best day of the week . How fine it is that every day holds some special joy in work or play ! But you all know the highest joy is mine . I am named for the golden sun that gives light to the world . On Sunday men think of the inner light that makes them love the good and the true and persuades them to do right . To-day the family is united , and in the morning with fresh garments and happy faces they seek the knowledge of a higher life . Around the dinner table they talk happily together of their work and play , and they plan how they may do better work during the next week . Love and peace are in all hearts . A desire to help the weak and poor and sad is in every soul . I am happy and blest to be Sunday .

castItem.role: WITCH
castItem.roleDesc: SANDMAN , CHILDREN

stage.stage: Hänsel . I wish mother would come home ! I 'm cold and hungry . I 'm tired of bread . I want some milk and sugar .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Hush , Hänsel ; do n't be cross ! Hänsel . If we only had something good to eat : eggs , and butter and meat . Oh , dear !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Dear Hänsel , if you will stop crying , I 'll tell you a secret . Hänsel . Oh , what is it ? Something nice ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Yes , indeed . Look in this jug ! It is full of milk . Mother will make us a pudding for supper . Hänsel . Goody , goody ! How thick the cream is ! Let me taste it .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Are n't you ashamed , you naughty boy ! Take your finger out of the cream . We must go back to work . When mother comes she will be cross if you have not finished the broom . Hänsel . I 'll not work any more . I want to dance .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: So do I. I like to dance better than to work . Come , let us dance and sing . Brother , come and dance with me , Both my hands I offer thee ; Right foot first , Left foot then , Round about and back again . Hänsel . I can n't dance . Show me what I ought to do .

lg.l: Look at me . Do this .
With your foot you tap , tap , tap !
With your hands you clap , clap , clap !
Right foot first ,
Left foot then ,
Round about and back again .
Hänsel
With your hands you clap , clap , clap !
With your foot you tap , tap , tap !
Right foot first ,
Left foot then ,
Round about and back again .
That is fine , brotherkin ! Soon you will dance as well as I .
Come , try again .
With your head you nick , nick , nick !
With your fingers click , click , click !
Right foot first ,
Left foot then ,
Round about and back again .
Hänsel .
O Gretel dear , O sister dear ,
Come dance and sing with me .
Gretel .
O Hänsel dear , O brother dear ,
Come dance and sing with me .
Tra , la , la , tra , la , la ,
La , la , la , la , tra , la , la .
Mother
What is all this noise ?
‘ Twas Hänsel . He wanted —
Hänsel . ‘ Twas Gretel . She said I —

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Hush , you noisy children ! What work have you done ? Gretel , your stocking is not done yet ; and where are your brooms , you lazy Hans ? You have knocked over the milk too ! What shall we have for supper ? Lazy folks can n't stay in my house . Take the basket and go to the woods for strawberries . And do n't dare to come back without them ! Off with you ! and be quick too !The children go out . Mother sits weeping .Oh ! I am so tired and hungry . Nothing in the house to eat . What shall I do for the poor hungry children — Oh , dear , what can I do !Goes to sleep , crying .Fatherenters , singingHillo , hilloo , hillo , hilloo , Little mother , where are you ? Motherlooking upWho is singing and making so much noise ?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I called you , for I am hungry and want my supper .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Your supper ! with nothing in the house to eat and nothing to drink .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Let us see . Open your eyes and look in my basket . Cheer up , mother !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What do I see ? Ham and butter and flour and sausage ! Where did you get all these good things , father ?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Hurrah , wo n't we have a merry time , wo n't we have a happy time ? I sold so many brooms at the fair that I could buy you all these good things and some tea besides .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Tea ! how good it smells and how glad I am ! Now I will cook the supper .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: But where are the children ? Hänsel ! Gretel ! Where are they ?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Oh , the bad children ! They did no work and they were singing and dancing and spilled the milk , so I sent them to the woods to pick some strawberries for supper .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Laughing and dancing ! Why should you be angry ? Where have they gone ?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: To the mountain .

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: To the mountain ! the home of the witch !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: What do you mean ? The witch ?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Yes , the old witch of the mountain turns all children to gingerbread and then she eats them .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: Eats them ! Oh , my children , my pretty little children ! Come , we must find them ! Hänsel , Gretel , where are you ?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: I will go with you , mother . Do n't cry ! we will surely find them .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: See , my wreath is nearly done . Hänsel . And the basket is filled with strawberries . Wo n't mother be pleased ? We will have them for supper .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Let me put the wreath on you ! Hänsel . No , no ! boys do n't wear wreaths . Put it on your own head . You shall be queen of the woods .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Then I must have a nosegay , too . Hänsel . Now you have a scepter and a crown . You shall have some strawberries , too . Do n't they taste good ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Let me feed you . Hänsel . And I 'll feed you . Do n't be greedy !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Oh , Hänsel , the berries are all gone . What naughty children we are ! We must pick some more now for mother . Hänsel . I do n't care , I was so hungry . But it is too late to pick strawberries now . Let us go home .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Let us hurry ; it is dark and I 'm afraid . Hänsel . Pooh , I 'm not afraid . But I can n't see the way . Gretel , we 're lost !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: What was that ? Hänsel . What ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: That shining there in the dark ! Hänsel . Pshaw , do n't be afraid ! That is a birch tree in its silver dress .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: There , see ! a lantern is coming this way . Hänsel . That is a will-of-the-wisp with its little candle .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: I 'm frightened , I 'm frightened ! I wish I were home ! Hänsel . Gretelkin , stick close to me ! I 'll take care of you .

lg.l: See ! what is that little man in gray ?
Hänsel . I see him , too . I wonder who he is !
Sandman
With my little bag of sand
By every child 's bedside I stand .
Then little tired eyelids close ,
And little limbs have sweet repose .
Then from the starry sphere above
The angels come with peace and love .
Then slumber , children , slumber ,
For happy dreams are sent you
Through the hours you sleep .
Hänsel . I 'm sleepy . Let us go to sleep .
Let us say our prayers first .
Both .
When at night I go to sleep
Fourteen angels watch do keep :
Two my head are guarding ,
Two my feet are guiding ,
Two are on my right hand ,
Two are on my left hand ,
Two who warmly cover ,
Two who o'er me hover ,
Two to whom ‘ tis given
To guide my steps to Heaven .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Good night , dear brother . Hänsel . Good night , dear sister . Do n't be afraid . I 'll take care of you .

div.head: SCENE III .— In the Wood — Morning

sp.speaker: Gretel

sp.speaker: Gretel

lg.l: It looks good enough to eat .
Hänsel . Let 's nibble it !
Nibble , nibble , manikin !
Who 's nibbling at my housekin ?
Hänsel . Oh , did you hear ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: It 's the wind ! Hänsel . Never mind , let us eat the cake . I 'm hungry . Take a bite ! Is n't it good ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Yes , and look at the candy ! What a funny fence this is ! It looks like little boys and girls made of gingerbread with sugar trimmings . I wonder who lives in this house ?The Gingerbread Woman comes out of the house and speaks .IllustrationYou 've come to visit me , that is sweet , You charming children , so good to eat ! Hänsel . Who are you , ugly one ? Let me go !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Take your arms away from me ! The Gingerbread Witch . Come into my house , little children ! You may have sugarplums and peaches and cherries and candies and everything nice that little folks like ! Hänsel . No , I wo n't ! I do n't want to go into your house . I want to go home !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: I do n't like you , Mrs . Gingerbread ! You are n't nice like my mother . I want to go home to my own mother ! The Gingerbread Witch . Come , dear little Gretel . You must go in with me . We 'll leave Hänsel in this little house outside . He must get fatter , so we will give him many good things to eat . Get in , Hänsel . I must lock you in ! Hänsel . What are you going to do with me ? The Gingerbread Witch . I 'll fatten you up nicely and then you will see ! Now I 'll go inside for some sugarplums . You wait here , Gretel , until I come back . Hocus , pocus , malus locus ! now you can n't move !Goes in .Hänsel . Listen , Gretel ! Watch the old witch and see everything she does to me . Hush , she 's coming back ! The Gingerbread Witch . Now , Hans , eat this raisin . It will make you fat ! Now , Gretel , you have stood still long enough . Hocus , pocus , elder bush ! Rigid body loosen , hush ! Then , Gretel , you must come with me , but Hans cannot move until he gets nice and fat like you . Run in , little daughter , and get some more nuts and raisins for him . I like plump little bodies like yours !Gretel goes in .Hänsel . Please let me out , Mrs . Gingerbread . The Gingerbread Witch . When you are fatter . Now I must look to my fire . It is burning well , and the oven will soon be hot enough to bake my dinner . When I change my gingerbread I 'll pop little Gretel in and shut the door .Gretel comes in very quietly and goes to Hans .Gretel . Hocus , pocus , elder bush ! Rigid body loosen , hush ! The Gingerbread Witch . What are you saying ?

lg.l: Oh , nothing ,— only ,—
The Gingerbread Witch . Only what ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Only , much good may it do to Hans ! The Gingerbread Witch . Poor Hans is too thin , but I hope the raisins and nuts will be good for him . But , you , my plump little Gretel , are just fat enough — come , peep in the oven and see if the gingerbread is ready ! HänselsoftlySister dear , have a care ; She means to hurt you , so beware ! GretelshylyI do n't understand what I am to do ! The Gingerbread Witch . Do ? Why , open the oven door ! Hänsel . Sister dear , now take care !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: I 'm such a goose , I do n't understand . The Gingerbread Witch . Do as I say , it 's only play ! This is the way .

sp.speaker: Children sing
sp.p: One little push , bang goes the door , clang ! Now , let us be happy , dancing so merrily . Hurrah ! Hurrah ! Hänsel . Why , see the children , Gretel . The fence is moving ! The gingerbread children are real children , but their eyes are shut !

sp.speaker: The Children
sp.p: We are saved ! We are saved !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Who are you ? Why do you keep your eyes shut ? You 're sleeping and yet you are talking !

sp.speaker: The Children
sp.p: O touch us , we pray , that we may awake ! Hänsel . The witch has changed them into gingerbread children . I know what to do . Let us say what the witch said to you , and what you said to me ! Hänsel and Gretel . Hocus , pocus , elder bush ! Rigid body loosen , hush !

lg.stage: Opening their eyes and running toward Hänsel and Gretel .
lg.l: We thank you , we thank you both !

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Oh , I am so glad !

sp.speaker: The Children
sp.p: The spell is broken and we are free . The witch can do us no more harm . Come , let us shout for glee ! Hänsel . Come , children all , and form a ring , Join hands together , while we sing .

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Oh , Hänsel dear , I wish father and mother were here ! Hänsel . Look , Gretel ! There they are !

Gretel ! How glad I am we have found you safe and well !
Hänsel . Oh , father , we must tell you all about the Gingerbread Witch !

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: My dear children , were you frightened ?

sp.speaker: Gretel
sp.p: Yes , mother , I was . But , mother , Hänsel comforted me , and we said our prayers and went to sleep .

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.p: The good angels watched over you and brought you back ! Come , let us go to the village and take all these dear children to their mothers . Wo n't they be surprised and happy to see their dear children again ?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Come , children !

div.head: SCENE II .— Years later , when Alfred is King

stage.head: KING ALFRED , OSCAR THE EARL , ODULPH , THE EARL 'S SON

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: All the others have gone back to their homes . In no other way can ye serve me . Wherefore do ye go about to weep and break my heart ?

sp.speaker: Oscar
sp.p: We weep , royal Alfred , because thou hast forbidden us to share thy fortunes ; as if we were the swarm of summer flies , who follow only while the sun shineth .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: My valiant Oscar , and you my faithful Odulph , listen to me . I do not despair . The time is not ripe now for further war . Our foes the Danes have conquered us for a time . I trust that the time will come when we shall drive them from our land . But we must do that which seems best for the present and seek to be more successful in the future . We must not sit down and weep ; no , this rather shall you do . Go back to your own people and keep me in their memory . When the Dane rules most cruelly , then rise up and cry aloud in the ears of the people , “ Alfred the king yet liveth ! ” Then gather the soldiers and I shall come to lead them to victory .

sp.speaker: Oscar
sp.p: Thou shalt be obeyed , my royal lord . I will return to my men and do as thou hast said . But let my son Odulph stay with thee , if only as thy servant .

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: Well will I serve thee , my royal lord . It is not well for the king to fare alone .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I am well content to serve myself , or even to be servant to others , until a happier time shall come . If Odulph desires to serve me , it shall be by bringing good tidings of your success with my people . When the time comes that we may again fight for our country , let him bring me the welcome message . Then we will free our country from the Danish yoke .

sp.speaker: Oscar
sp.p: Farewell , my royal master , since thou wilt have it so .

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: And may the time soon come when I shall bring the message to thee !

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Farewell , my loyal friends . All will be well .

div.head: SCENE III .— In the Peasant 's Home

stage.head: KING ALFRED , PEASANT CUDRED , WIFE SWITHA

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Save you , good father ! May a Saxon stranger , whom the Danish robbers have made homeless , share a lodging with thy master 's cattle for the night ?

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Wilt thou swear to me that thou art not a Dane in disguise ?

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I say to thee , my friend , I am no Dane , but a true Saxon .

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Then thou shalt share the calf 's crib to-night . Perchance thou art hungry , too ?

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: To say truth , father , I have not broken my fast to-day ; neither have I had aught to drink save from these marshy streams . I shall be right thankful for some food , even a crust of coarsest rye bread .

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Rye bread , forsooth ! Thou talkest of dainties indeed ! Thou wilt get nothing better than flat oaten cakes here .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I have always wished to taste an oaten cake .

lg.l: Follow me , then , and thou shalt have thy desire . Switha ,
Switha !

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Well , I hear thee !

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Switha , I have brought thee home a guest who will be glad to partake of our supper .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: A guest ! And thinkest thou I 've naught better to do than broil fish and bake cakes for all the vagabonds who roam the land ?

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Patience , good Switha . I have not asked thee to cook for a vagabond . This is an honest Saxon whom it will be charity to feed and shelter for the night .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Let me hold the torch and see this Saxon guest . Thou lookest like a guest of fashion , sorry fellow !

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Cease thy scolding talk , woman ! I see by this light that our guest hath not been used to beg for charity from such as thou . Why be so hard of heart and by thy rude taunts make bitter the food he must receive from our hands ?

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: I have heard that charity begins at home , and I am sure we are poor enough .

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Not poor enough to refuse food to the hungry , such as it is . Here is fish , and here an oaten cake which you wish to taste .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Thanks for your goodness , kind host . Indeed , I am hungry .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: You eat like a hungry wolf .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: And now I am hungry no longer . I thank you both for a good supper , and I hope you will never be sorry you have given charity to a stranger . Now , Cudred , I shall be glad to sleep .

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: This way , then , to the bed of straw . Now , tell me truly , art thou not some mighty earl in disguise ?

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I am Alfred , thy king — I know from thy goodness to me when thou thoughtest me a beggar that thou art a good man , therefore I confide in thee . I know thou wilt not betray thy king .

sp.speaker: Cudred
sp.p: Not all the gold of Denmark should tempt me to commit so base a crime , but we must not let Switha know who thou art , my royal master .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I shall be careful . Soon , I hope , my friends will bring me word that my army awaits me , when I shall again try to set my country free .

div.head: SCENE IV .— In the Peasant 's Hut

sp.speaker: King Alfred
sp.p: It rains so hard to-day that I cannot hunt , so will mend my bow and make some new arrows . May I sit by your fire , good dame Switha ?

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Yes , and as I have made a good batch of cakes you might watch them bake .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Gladly will I watch them . Show me what I must do .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Turn them often before the fire , thus , so that they will not burn . Now I will go for more wood for the fire .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: How long , I wonder , must I remain in hiding . It is very hard to wait . If only I knew how my people were faring . Will the time never come when I can rule over England and unite my people ? So many plans have I for their happiness and progress . Schools we must have . The Bible must be translated for the people to read . Roads must be built and the country made safe for all . How long must I sit in Cudred 's cottage mending arrows when my heart wishes to help my suffering people ! Switharunning inI thought I smelled them burning ! Oh , thou lazy , useless fellow ! Thou art ready enough to eat the cakes , but too lazy to keep them from burning . No wonder thou hast no home , idle as thou art .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: I pray thee , good dame , forgive me . I was lost in thought of happier days and forgot my duty . Really I am sorry .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Ay , ay , that is always the way with thee . That smooth tongue of thine is better to thee than silver or gold ; for it obtains for thee food , lodging , and friends , and softens all the wrath thy faults provoke . However , I shall set by all the burnt cakes for thy portion of the week 's bread , I promise thee ; and thou shalt have no other till they are all eaten .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: My good mistress , here comes a pilgrim boy to ask thy charity . May I bestow one of these cakes on him ?

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Thou mayest do what thou wilt with thine own , man ! but do not presume to give away my property to idle fellows like thyself .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: But , mistress , may I not give him that which was to have been my portion for dinner ?

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: No , indeed ! I have enough to do with feeding one vagrant without adding all the lazy pilgrims who pass by .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: See , mistress , my amulet ! I will give thee this jewel , Switha , if thou wilt permit me to feed this poor pilgrim .

sp.speaker: Switha
sp.p: Very well , then . Give him thy portion while I go and hide the jewel .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Welcome , Odulph ! Tell me thy tidings . I hunger for good news .

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: My tidings , royal Alfred , are these : Hubba , the Dane , the terror of England , is slain , and his banner of the Raven waves in my father 's hall !

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: What ? Is thy father 's castle in the possession of the Danes ?

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: Not so , my royal master ; but the banner of the Danes , captured by your victorious Saxons , hangs in his hall . We were pent up in the castle by the Danes till our provisions failed . When the last loaf was eaten , and our archers had launched their last arrows , my valiant father led the garrison in an attack upon the foe .

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: Brave Oscar ! And you defeated them !

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: Yes , because of the carelessness of the Danes . They believed they had us in their power , and they never dreamed we would leave the castle walls . Few as we were , we fell upon them and slew their chiefs . The soldiers fled , and left our men victorious . Then my father raised the cry , “ Alfred the king ! ” All the country is calling , “ Alfred the king ! ”

sp.speaker: Alfred
sp.p: The time is ripe . I thank you , Odulph . Your father is a noble man , and I shall know how to show a king 's gratitude to you both . Shall we go ?

sp.speaker: Odulph
sp.p: Lead on , King Alfred , England is ready . Soon you shall head your army shouting , “ Long live King Alfred ! ”

div.head: SCENE II .— In the Abbot 's Hall

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: This day a year ago Sir Richard Lea borrowed four hundred pounds from me . He promised to pay in a year or lose his land . If he does not return to-day , the land will be mine .

sp.speaker: The Prior
sp.p: The day is now far spent . Perhaps he will come yet .

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: I am sure I hope he will not . I trust he has left England .

sp.speaker: The Prior
sp.p: The land is worth much more than four hundred pounds . It were a pity if he did not redeem it .

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: Thou art ever crossing me ! Speak no more about it ! Where is the Lord Justice ?IllustrationLord JusticeentersHere I am . I have just come from London to do justice on that Knight . Where is he ?

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: The Knight has failed to come with the money and this is the day when the land falls to me .

sp.speaker: Lord Justice
sp.p: I dare swear he will not come and thou shalt have his lands . I now declare that the knight , Sir Richard Lea , has failed to keep his promise and his lands are — The Knightentering and kneeling before the AbbotRejoice with me , Sir Abbot . I am come to keep my day .

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: What dost thou say ? Hast brought the money ? The Knightto try the AbbotNot a penny , but —

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: What dost thou here without the money ?

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: To ask your kindness and patience , Sir Abbot , for a longer time .

sp.speaker: Lord Justice
sp.p: The day has come . Thou losest thy land , Sir Knight , since thou canst not pay .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: Good Lord Justice , help me against my foes ! I will surely pay , but must have more time .

sp.speaker: Lord Justice
sp.p: I am sorry for thee , Sir Richard , but the law is plain . Either pay your debt or lose your land .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: Sir Abbot , I pray thee , have pity .

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: Get the land when thou canst , thou gettest no pity from me .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: By my faith , then , if I get not my land again , thou shalt pay dearly for it .

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: Get thee gone , false knight ! Darest thou threaten me ?

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: False knight I am not , for I have fought well for my king .

sp.speaker: Lord Justice
sp.p: Sir Abbot , the day is not yet gone . What wilt thou give the knight to hold his peace ?

sp.speaker: The Abbot
sp.p: A hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: Lord Justice
sp.p: Make it two hundred .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: No , nor nine hundred . Ye shall not have my land ! Here , Sir Abbot , are the four hundred pounds . Had you been less covetous , I would have given interest . Now , get you gone , all of you ; and learn to deal more justly and kindly with those in need .They go out .Lady LeaenteringOh , my dear husband ! how glad I am to hear your voice again .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: Happy am I to see you and to be at home again . I must tell you how kind Robin Hood has been to me .

sp.speaker: Lady Lea
sp.p: Robin Hood your friend ? Is he not the outlaw of the forest ?

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: Yes ; but he is kind to all who are unhappy or oppressed . He saved me from leaving England and gave me money to redeem my land .

sp.speaker: Lady Lea
sp.p: How I long to thank him for his goodness to you .

sp.speaker: The Knight
sp.p: In a year we will go to him and repay the four hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: Lady Lea
sp.p: I shall be glad to see him and his merry men , and try to thank them all .
